text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with crepe Annette's
that's right I'm going to show you how
to make what I consider the most
beautiful sausage in the world it's also
I believe one of the easiest and most
delicious so what's the catch well to
make it you have to use this caul fat
but relax it's nothing more than the fat
vein membrane that holds in an animal's
guts but anyway we'll get to that in a
moment
because before we worry about the
outside we have to mix up the inside and
for that we're going to need some ground
pork and the key here is you're going to
need coarsely ground pork so do not grab
that package from the meat case that's
way too fine I want you to actually talk
to the butcher and tell me you need some
coarsely ground pork for sausage and I
guess you could say for cr√©pinette but
unfortunately I think seven out of ten
American butchers would reply crepe of
what crepe oh-hoo and by the way this
was sold as 85% lean fifteen percent fat
but I can tell just by looking at it
that's not even close this looks to be
more like 25 to 30 percent fat which is
what we want but anyway we'll go over
that stuff on the blog for now we're
going to go ahead and add the rest of
the ingredients so I'm going to toss in
some kosher salt as well as some freshly
ground black pepper I'm also going to do
a few shakes of cayenne pepper and
suggest you do the same I'm also going
to do a little touch of sage not too
much I'm going to do about a teaspoon of
finely sliced fresh sage leaf and then
we'll finish this off with our fruit and
nuts so I'm going to toss in some dried
apricot which I finely diced as well as
some roughly chopped pistachio and
please note there's no such thing as a
crepe in that recipe this is a technique
so these just happen to be the
ingredients I'm using today but you can
change it up and put whatever you want
in I mean you are the Joan Jett of your
crepe net so it's up to you to make sure
this rocks and then all we're going to
do is take a fork and mix this until
it's just combined if for me the fork
does a great job here of being able to
mix this without over mixing it too much
if we use the big spoon or even our hand
I think you might risk overworking this
so I just use the tip of a fork like
this until like I say it's just combined
at which point we can wrap it up until
we're ready to use it or we can actually
start making crepe and that's now which
is what I'm going to do
and as I mentioned earlier for that
we're going to need some caul fat which
comes all wadded up usually packed in
water and when you unfurl it it should
look something like this alright it's
basically a see-through super thin
membrane featuring a kind of lacy
structure of fat veins that kind of hold
it all together and all we're going to
do here is trim a piece that's about two
or three inches bigger than our crepe
net and no it doesn't have to be a
square piece but that it's kind of easy
to work with
and what we're going to do is take a
quarter of our filling which is going to
give us a six ounce crepe net and we'll
form that into a patty about 3/4 of an
inch thick
and place that right in the center and
then we'll simply wrap our crepe Annette
as shown so that all our seams end up on
the bottom and if you think you need to
you can trim off a little bit of the
excess but be careful we do our full
coverage and that's it a perfect 6 ounce
crepe Annette and if you're still
watching once those your savages go
ahead and transfer those onto a plate
and continue on with the remaining
mixture and by the way caul fat is like
a box of chocolates you never know what
you're going to get so for whatever
reason if you don't have nice big pieces
to work with you could totally overlap a
couple smaller pieces and do it this way
it'll work just the same the only
difference is you might get a little
extra caul fat but according to most
chefs that would not be considered a
problem but anyway the point is you can
use a couple smaller pieces to wrap
these up and by the way you don't think
you can but trust me you can get caul
fat from your butcher any butcher in
town will be able to get it but if not
it's also very easy to buy frozen online
so say goodbye to those excuses then
once our crepe in that hour set we have
a couple choices you can cook these
immediately if you want but I think they
come out better if you wrap them up and
pop in the fridge overnight I can't
prove it but I actually think these come
out a little more flavorful if you do so
that's what I did
but either way when you're ready to eat
this is how we're going to cook them up
so what we'll do is we'll heat a little
bit of vegetable oil in a skillet over
medium heat and we will place our crepe
Anette in seam side up alright so we
want that nice smooth side facing down
and we'll go ahead and let that side
Brown for about three or four minutes at
which point we will flip them over and
we will give the other side about three
or four minutes and basically what's
happening here is our call fat is sort
of getting fused to our pork mixture
and not only does it create a gorgeous
appearance but it really does add a lot
of flavor and moisture and speaking of
fat is these cook a lot of that's going
to render out and I do usually blot some
of it out with a paper towel and
probably suggest you do the same and
then what's going to happen after both
sides of brown for about three or four
minutes I'm going to pour in a little
splash of white wine cover this and let
it go for another five minutes so that's
what I did and after about five minutes
it look like this and as you can see at
this point I do like to give em a little
toss and those amazing smelling pan
drippings and by the time we've tossed
those around and they've cooked for
another minute or two uncovered that Y
should be pretty much reduced and our
crepe net should be cooked through and
at this point you could totally serve
these up as is but if you want and I do
I'm going to turn off my heat and swirl
in a little piece of butter just to give
that already shiny sauce a little extra
shine and body and richness and flavor
so yes this part is optional but you
know what people rarely say this is
delicious but I wish they didn't add
that extra butter so I'm going to swirl
that in and as soon as that disappears
we are ready to plate up so I'm gonna go
ahead and serve mine up simply next to a
little slaw and really this thing is so
gorgeous and glistening it doesn't even
need the sauce but let's go ahead and
spoon some over anyway then last but not
least I'm going to finish mine with a

that shouldn't bother anyone and that's

it also adds a ton of flavor and some
